Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Evaluating the Market Potential of the Mechanix Sketch Recognition Software
Award.AbstractNarration:
Introductory engineering courses within large universities often have annual enrollments exceeding several hundreds of students, while MOOCS and online classes have even larger classes. It is very challenging to achieve differentiated instruction in classrooms with class sizes and student diversity of such great magnitude. In such classes, professors can only assess whether students have mastered a concept by using multiple-choice questions. However, in a multiple choice scenario, students only have to identify the answer rather than create the answer, and the feedback received is only of a binary nature (right or wrong). Additionally, a growing concern among engineering educators is that students are losing both the critical skill of sketched diagrams and the ability to take a real system and reduce it to an accurate but simplified free-body diagram (FBD). The proposed software program, Mechanix, provides an artificially intelligent, scalable online instructional platform for engineering and physics instruction.

Mechanix is a sketch-based tutoring system for engineering students enrolled in statics courses. Mechanix not only allows students to hand-draw solutions with planar truss and free body diagrams, just as they would with pencil and paper, but it also checks the student's work. It uses sketch recognition to determine both the component shapes and features of the sketched diagram and the relationships between those shapes and features. Mechanix then uses those relationships to determine whether a student's work is correct and why it is incorrect, enabling Mechanix to return immediate personalized feedback to the student otherwise not possible in large classes. The iterative correction process facilitates student learning. Additionally Mechanix relieves the instructor of the resource intensive burden of grading even very complex, hand-sketched work. This enables the instructor to explore creative problem solving material that may be otherwise too resource intensive to evaluate. The Mechanix software has been successfully deployed in the classroom at three schools with over 300 participating students, showing promising learning and student engagement results. In this project the I-Corps team seeks to determine customer needs in those markets where Mechanix may have the greatest impact in its current form: learning institutions, instructors, students and providers of educational content. The team also seeks to determine the alignment of Mechanix with those needs and changes that may be required; and to determine whether there exist additional markets where this technology may be applied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mechanix is a sketch recognition system that automatically understands and provides personalized immediate feedback to students on their hand-drawn free body diagram and truss homework or quiz problems. The Mechanix software program provides an artificially intelligent, scalable online instructional platform for engineering and physics instruction. This includes sophisticated creativity- and design-based problems, otherwise impossible to grade or manage at large scales. At the individual classroom scale the software relieves instructor pain and workload by providing automatic feedback to students (“24/7 office hours”) and automatically grading assignments. For students, it provides 24/7 dynamic feedback and promotes higher engagement with the material, especially valuable to remote, marginal or at-risk students. At larger scales, in MOOC and online course environments, the software provides feedback and grading support for massively scaled, distributed, and asynchronous learning. This reduces online course overhead, while increasing one-on-one student feedback, retention and throughput. Assignments are easily created and added by individual instructors in their language of choice, providing the potential for rapid globalization.

 

The purpose of this project was to determine the marketability of the Mechanix software and sketch recognition technology through the iCorps program. We collected interview data and through well over 100 interviews, taken both during and after the iCorps program, it was discovered that there is an extreme need for the technology and that it is highly marketable, but that the markets are complex.

 

The following value propositions were discovered: Feedback increases student learning opportunities during problem solving. Automated graded diagrams reduce grading effort/time. Diagram analysis can reduce cheating. Automated understanding of hand-drawn diagrams expands the class of problems that can be assigned. Rapid feedback addresses student knowledge gaps more quickly. Drawing diagrams engages student attention. Hand-drawn diagrams facilitate collaborative problem solving. Diagram understanding provides formative assessment at scale. Immediate personalized feedback on the process of problem solving, including drawing, increases student retention. Reduced grading time without sacrificing quality feedback increases teacher retention. Hand drawn diagrams support differentiated learning. Hand-drawn diagrams can also contribute to integrated Sketching/GIS Spatial Learning. Providing feedback at different stages of problem solving, including the drawing, allows for scaffolding of science problems. Giving feedback on the diagrams and the equations that support the computations allow for focus on process and understanding of the problem rather than the correct answer. Collating students’ feedback is key to evaluating their progress.


Almost every interview emphasized the importance of teaching the problem solving process and the place of diagramming  in solving engineering and science problems, and lamented how current technology fails to support this. Customer segments include Middle School, High School, and University students, teachers, and parents, with a focus on courses/classes with low TA support, and publishers of educational material, including MOOCS. A resegmented market focusing only on High School courses gives a target market of $99 million, a served available market of $7.14 billion, and a total available market of $18.33 billion. The interviews also elucidated the importance of a web-based platform due to many port restrictions in high schools. Additionally, the interviews highlighted the powerful impact that could also occur by broadening the subject base and introducing more options for adding/editing more problems to the database.  

 

The PI on this project was Dr. Tracy Hammond, Director of the Sketch Recognition Lab and Professor of Computer Science at Texas A&M University. The entrepreneurial lead on this project was Dr. Michael Helms, a Research Scientist II at the Center for Education Integrating Science, Mathematics and Computing at the Georgia Institute of Technology. The mentor on this project was Mr. Richard Berman, Interim Dean of the University of South Florida Patel College of Global Sustainability, Visiting Social Entrepreneurship Professor at the MUMA College of Business, and a Courtesy Professor at the Institute for Innovation & Advanced Discovery.
